A novel sustainable approach for the synthesis of 2-ethyl 1,3 dioxolane and various short to long-chain or aromatic cyclic acetals through a tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction using Rh oxide nanoparticle supported on zirconium phosphate has been established. The Rh oxide nanoparticle supported on zirconium phosphate was synthesized and characterized by various physicochemical methods. The SEM and TEM analysis revealed the average particle size of rhodium oxide was found to be ∼7.56 nm in 2%Rh@ZrP catalyst. Furthermore, the synthesized catalyst was employed to carry out a tandem hydroformylation reaction in a green solvent (ethylene glycol). Experimental results demonstrated that 2 wt.% of Rhodium on zirconium phosphate efficiently activated olefins, leading to the selective formation of cyclic acetals (60–99%) at 80°C for 6 h. In this cascade reaction, significant selectivity towards the desired product, linear cyclic acetals was observed for styrenes. This can be attributed to highly dispersed Rh oxide nanoparticles and plentiful acidic sites on the zirconium phosphate supports, which played a crucial role in tandem hydroformylation and acetalization reactions. The catalyst exhibited the ability to be reused three times without losing significant catalytic activity or selectivity. This is the first report on the synthesis of a fuel additive and other cyclic acetals via a tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction using heterogeneous catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Zirconium phosphate Rhodium oxide nanoparticles Tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction Ethylene glycol Cyclic acetals Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The Hydroformylation reaction (addition of CO/H2 to olefins) is one of the most extensively researched processes and is widely used for the industrial production of aldehyde via a transition metal-catalyzed homogeneous reaction [1–3]. Co and Rh-based catalysts have been used in the industrial hydroformylation of olefins to obtain aldehydes [1,3]. These aldehydes are commonly used as intermediates in the synthesis of bulk and fine chemicals. However, to convert these fine chemicals into valuable products requires additional steps. Tandem hydroformylation offers a beneficial solution over multistep reactions, as it can be combined with other organic reactions (such as Amination, Aldol reaction, Acetalization, Hydrogenation, mannich reaction, etc.) to produce amines, α-ß unsaturated products, alcohols, acetals, and other fine chemicals. This approach aligns with the principles of atom economy and low energy consumption in green chemistry [1,4]. The advantage of tandem hydroformylation lies in its ability to reduce the two-step separation and purification processes, making this protocol particularly suitable for industrial applications. Among the several downstream goods derived from aldehydes, acetals are one of the valuable chemicals; they are commonly used as ingredients in perfumery or flavor chemicals, solvents, and intermediates or final products in pharmaceuticals, petrochemicals, agrochemicals, and fine chemicals processes [5]. Diols are excellent protecting groups for carbonyl compounds during multistep organic synthesis to obtain chemoselectivity. Notably, the obtained chemicals play a vital role in medicinal, organic, carbohydrate, and drug design chemistry [6]. Acetalization stands as an important method for the protection of carbonyl compounds. It is accomplished by reacting aldehyde or ketone compounds with alcohols or diols in the presence of Lewis or Brønsted acids [7–10]. However, this reaction has some drawbacks, including recovery and reuse, high corrosiveness, and severe environmental pollution. Heterogeneous acidic catalysts have a very high impact on the large-scale production of fine chemicals [11–13]. A tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction represents the most reliable method for producing acetals from olefins in a single step. The initial stage of this reaction involves the hydroformylation of olefin to selectively produce aldehydes, which are subsequently converted into acetals in the presence of alcohols and diols (Scheme 1 ). Currently, the functionalization of polyols is a promising strategy for converting petrochemicals and renewable raw materials into fine chemicals [14–16]. However, numerous methods have been reported for the synthesis of acetals through acetalization [17–20]. The production of cyclic acetals is significant due to their high demand for various practical applications. Notably, 1,2 diol-like ethylene glycol (EG) based short-chain acetals are important intermediates for organic synthesis [4,12,21-25]. This study investigated the hydroformylation-acetalization (HFA) reaction using styrene and ethylene glycol (EG) as a model substrate. From the literature, it is observed that several HFA reactions have been proposed to synthesize cyclic acetals from C2 - C12 alkenes using different catalytic systems, such as homogeneous catalysts [4,26-32], ionic liquids [33,34], biphasic medium [35,36], heterogeneous or solid acids catalyst [14,37–40]. To address the drawbacks of the homogeneous system, researchers have developed biphasic medium heterogeneous catalysts for HFA reactions. Karakhanov et al. reported on the HFA of 1-octene and polyols in the presence of water-soluble rhodium precursor. This ligand provides the highest selectivity, about 95%, and easy product separation from the reaction mixture [35]. In another report, they employed a homogeneous catalyst combined with cation exchange resins for HFA of 1-octene. Although resins can be easily separable, the separation of the ligand from the reaction mixture is very difficult [38]. Ali et al. synthesized Rh(I), or Rh(III) impregnated on MCM-41, which was used in a hydroformylation-acetalization reaction, achieving a selectivity of 94% for acetals [39]. Moreover, the use of ligands in a biphasic system may increase the cost of catalysts. From an environmental perspective, heterogeneous catalysts have garnered significant attention due to their recyclability, ease of separation, low cost, and eco-friendliness. However, additives such as heteropolyacids and phosphorus-based ligands were essential in some cases [37–39]. For example, Li et al. synthesized 87.1% acetals with 45.8 % linear acetals of styrene by tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction using Rh/SiO2 catalyst at 120 ℃ for 10 h [14]. In our previous report, we used Iminophosphine rhodium complex immobilized on carbon for the same reaction, and we achieved up to 87% conversion of styrene with 56% selectivity towards linear product [41]. In this study, we explored Rh-based solid acid catalysts (ligand-free) for tandem hydroformylation-acetalization of alkenes under mild conditions (Scheme 1). The Rh@ZrP catalyst achieved up to 99% acetal selectivity, comparable to homogeneous catalyst results [4,34]. Moreover, we synthesized fuel additives using the same Rh@ZrP catalysts, which were previously reported by a homogeneous tandem hydroformylation-acetalization process [18,36]. Rh oxide nanoparticles enabled olefin hydroformylation, while surface acidic sites on the zirconium support facilitated successive acetalization of aldehydes with alcohol to synthesize acetals. This sustainable approach streamlines acetal synthesis, reducing by-product production and simplifying the process compared to traditional routes [14]. Additionally, we explored olefin's scope and studied catalytic mechanisms. Experimental section Materials and methods Zirconium oxychlorideoctahydrate (ZrOCl28H2O, 96.0%), and phosphoric acid (85%), were purchased from S. D. Fine chemical. [RhCl (CO)2]2 purchased from Alfa Aser. Ethylene glycol and methanol were purchased from Finar Chemicals Pvt. Ltd. Styrene, 4-Methylstyrene, 4-Chlorostyrene, 4-Bromostyrene, 4-tert-butylstyrene, and 4-methoxystyrene was purchased from TCI chemicals, ethylene, and propane gas from Raj Sons (Bhavnagar). 1,2 Propanediol and 1,3-Butanediol, 1-Pentene, 1-Hexene, 1-Octene, 1-Nonene, 1-Decene from Sigma Aldrich and used without any further purification. Synthesis of ZrP ZrP was synthesized by following the reported procedure with slight modification [42,43]. Typically, ZrOCl28H2O (2 g) was heated at a refluxing temperature with 20 mL H3PO4 (2.4 M) for 24 h. The white precipitate was cooled to room temperature, filtered, and washed with copious amounts of de-ionized water until it was chloride-free and the pH of the filtrate neutral. The solid white cake was collected and dried in an oven at 110°C for 24 h. The dried solid material was grounded with a mortar pestle into fine powders. The obtained final material is denoted as ZrP (1.9 g). Impregnation of Rh on ZrP in H2O The above synthesized ZrP was used as a support for the impregnation of Rh metal by following the technique described in the literature [21,44]. [RhCl(CO)2]2 was impregnated on the ZrP in the presence of H2O as a solvent through an ion-exchange mechanism. In a typical synthesis, ZrP (1 g) was dispersed in deionized water (15 mL) at 50°C, and the resulting suspension was treated with a solution of [RhCl(CO)2]2 (30 mL) in various Rh wt% in water (an additional amount of Rh). Furthermore, the above method was used to synthesize catalysts with different 1, 2, and 3 wt% of rhodium loading. The resulting suspension was heated at reflux temperature for four days. An entire conversation between the hydrogen ions of the P–OH groups and cations could not be completed at temperatures below 80°C or in less than 3 d [45]. The obtained material was filtered by hot distilled water 15 mL to give a gray color solid. (i.e., until the filtrate was colorless). After this obtained solid product was dried in the oven at 110 °C for 12 h, the catalyst was calcined at 600 °C for 4 h to give the final product, Rh@ZrP (0.7 g), as a gray solid. Catalytic activity The hydroformylation-acetalization tandem reaction was carried out in a 50 mL Parr reactor (Hastelloy C276 autoclave) equipped with an internal thermocouple, magnetic stirring, and finger boat-type cooling. The reactor was charged with 2.4 mmol of the substrate, 50 mg of 2% Rh@ZrP, and 20 mL of ethylene glycol. Then, the reactor was fitted, and N2 was purged before the addition of syngas. Further, the reactor was pressurized to the desired pressure and heated to the desired temperature followed by stirring at 600 rpm. After completion of the reaction, the remaining syngas was released, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and the pressure was carefully released in a well-ventilated hood. Further, the liquid was withdrawn for analysis. After, the obtained reaction mixture was analyzed by GC–MS (Shimadzu, QP-2010) with an HP-5 column (30 m × 250 µm × 0.25 µm). Results and discussion Rh@ZrP material was obtained by slight modification in the previously reported procedures Scheme 2 . In this study, zirconium phosphate in H2O was stirred in an aqueous solution of [RhCl(CO)2]2 for 4 days under refluxing conditions. As a result, Rh@ZrP catalysts with varying wt.% of Rh (1, 2, 3) were obtained. ICP analysis was used to determine the Rh content. In addition, different physicochemical methods were used to characterize the catalyst to understand its structural properties (See SI-S1). Characterization of Rh@ZrP The Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectra of Rh@ZrP, as shown in Fig. 1 A, the appearance of a broad peak at 3250–3720 cm−1 attributed to the presence of the asymmetric stretching vibration of -OH in ZrP [46]. Another peak centered at 1626 cm−1 was attributed to the asymmetric bending vibration of -OH groups caused by the deformation of water molecules. The band at 1104 cm−1 corresponds to the O-P symmetrical stretching vibration peak of the -phosphate group (PO4). The intense bands at 521 cm−1 correspond to distortion modes of -PO4. The weak absorption peak at 764 cm−1 is attributed to the presence of P−O−P deforming vibration, signifying the presence of the polyphosphate groups in ZrP [47,48]. The as-synthesized Rh@ZrP catalyst was also characterized by powder-Xray diffraction (P-XRD), suggesting the material's amorphous nature because of its poor crystallinity, which is consistent with the measurement (Fig. 1B). In the XRD spectra, no obvious diffraction peaks related to Rh oxide species were observed for all the catalysts, which shows that the Rh oxides were highly dispersed on the zirconium phosphate supports. Furthermore, ICP-OES analysis confirms the presence of 1.5 wt% of Rh on the surface of zirconium phosphate support in 2% Rh@ZrP catalyst. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) was used to examine the surface morphology of the 2%Rh@ZrP material. Fig. 1C revealed the aggregate of the small particle with non-uniform morphology, whereas different magnifications (100 nm - 1 μm) show the SEM images of Rh@ZrP are shown in Fig. 1C-E. These images revealed that crystalline particles had aggregated to form spheres of various shapes and sizes. The magnified image of 2%Rh@ZrP shows that the large microcrystals are built with small 100–200 nm nanocrystals. The elemental mapping of this 2%Rh@ZrP showed the uniform distribution of the Rh, Zr, P, and O atoms across the entire catalyst (Fig. 1F). Furthermore, the elemental mapping of the material showed a uniform distribution of Rh, Zr, P, and O indicating that the nanoparticles were stabilized on the zirconium support (Fig. 1G-J). Fig. 1K shows the elemental analysis of the material using FE-SEM EDAX showed 2.26, 31.07, 15.07, and 51.6 wt.% of rhodium, zirconium, phosphorus, and oxygen in 2%Rh@ZrP catalyst, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2 , high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) analysis confirmed the presence of Rh oxide nanoparticles. Fig. 2A-B confirms the aggregate topography of the catalyst, which is consistent with the FE-SEM morphology of 2% Rh@ZrP. Moreover, Fig. 3 C confirms that nanoparticles of Rh oxides are well dispersed on the zirconium phosphate support. The d spacing of 0.25 nm corresponds to the lattice plane of Rh oxide (Rh2O3) (Fig. 2D) [49]. The average particle size of Rh oxide nanoparticles was ∼ 7.56 nm in 2%Rh@ZrP material. Furthermore, the interaction of P, O, Zr, and Rh in 2% Rh@ZrP was thoroughly investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), which is used to understand the surface composition and oxidation states. Fig. 3A and 3C illustrate the XPS spectra of the Zr and Rh regions in 2% Rh@ZrP, respectively. The XPS survey spectra of the 2% Rh@ZrP catalyst (See SI Fig. S1) confirm the presence of zirconium (Zr), rhodium (Rh), oxygen (O), and phosphorus (P). The elemental composition of this catalyst is given in SI (Table S1). The high-resolution Zr 3d is depicted in Fig. 3A. It could be deconvoluted into two signal peaks located at 182.7 eV for Zr 3d5/2 and 185.07 eV for Zr 3d3/2, which were characteristic of Zr4+ [48,49]. The high-resolution spectrum of the P 2p (Fig. 4 B) shows a broad intense peak at 133.31 eV, which corresponds to the pentavalent phosphorous (P5+) in the material [48,50]. It is shown in Fig. 3C that the spectrum of the binding energies of Rh 3d in the 2% Rh@ZrP exhibits intensive peaks at 307.63 and 312.4 eV, belonging to the Rh 3d5/2 and Rh 3d3/2 of the metallic Rh. The deconvoluted peaks reveal that the positive side shift could be attributed to the formation of partially positive charges on rhodium. (Fig. 2D) [49]. Further, the weak peaks that appeared at 309.59 and 314.19 eV correspond to the Rh oxide species, which is well supported by the d-spacing of rhodium oxide [50]. Furthermore, deconvolution of the O 1 s shown in Fig. 3D shows three peaks centered at 530.8 eV (PO4 3−)and 532.5 eV (Zr-O-H), which confirm the introduction of Zr and P [48,51-53]. The Brunauer –Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett –Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution of synthesized materials was shown in Fig. 3E-F and Table 1 , respectively. The specific surface area of 1%Rh@ZrP was 32.8m²/g with an increase in the loading of Rh from 1 to 3 wt%, the BET surface areas were slightly decreased. Simultaneously, the pore size and pore volume decrease, implying that pores blockage after loading increases. The acidic strength and the number of acidic sites on the 2%Rh@ZrP catalyst were characterized by NH3-TPD. The peak that appears at 100–180 °C can be assigned to weak acidic sites due to the desorption of NH3, which was weakly bound to the surface of zirconium phosphate and was around 0.44 mmol. In addition, the broad peak observed between 200and 550 °C can be attributed to medium to strong acidic sites was around 3.23 mmol (see SI Fig. S2). Hydroformylation - acetalization of styrene The catalytic activity of the as-synthesized Rh@ZrP catalysts, which have Lewis or Brønsted acidic sites, was examined for the hydroformylation-acetalization (HFA) reaction by selecting styrene as a model substrate in ethylene glycol (EG) were summarized in Fig. 4. Additionally, the catalyst zirconium phosphate is well known for various acid-catalyzed reactions due to its truthful acid properties [46,48,54-56]. The variation in the performance of each catalyst used for the HFA of styrene may be described as different Rh loading used for this study. The experimental study begins with the absence of rhodium or ligand (blank) at 80 °C with 30 bar (CO: H2) for 6 h, the result suggests that the activation of olefins seems very difficult (Fig. 4A). When PPh3 is added to [RhCl(CO)2]2, it shows a very low conversion of styrene to the targeted molecule with a side product (ethyl benzene). Unexpectedly, the addition of PPh3 to Rh(CO)2(acac) boosts the conversion of styrene, and selectivity towards cyclic acetals was 100% with 49% towards linear cyclic acetals (Fig. 4A). The synthesized Rh@ZrP catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic activity of tandem reaction and achieved 100% conversion with 100% selectivity of cyclic acetals and 65% selectively towards the linear cyclic acetals (Fig. 4A). Further, the effect of Rh loading on ZrP has investigated the catalytic activity of styrene to cyclic acetals (Fig. 4B). As we assume, the loading of the rhodium metal on a zirconium phosphate catalyst has a remarkable impact on the reaction and selectivity of acetals. In this study, we found that 1wt% of Rh@ZrP catalyst gives 96% conversion of styrene with 96% selectivity of cyclic acetals. As an increase in loading of rhodium from 1 to 2wt%, The complete conversion of styrene with 100% selectivity of cyclic acetals and 65% selectivity towards linear cyclic acetals. When we further increased the loading to 3wt%, it was observed that it decreased the selectivity of acetals, although there was the formation of a by-product (ethylbenzene). It is due to the hydrogenation of styrene, which is occurring due to the increased loading of rhodium. Rhodium is also an excellent metal for alkenes hydrogenation [57]. This result demonstrates that tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction indorsed the styrene conversion and increased the selectivity of desired linear products. The intermediate (aldehyde) of this reaction, which is formed in the first step of the reaction, can be further transformed into corresponding acetals. Additionally, the steric interruption was less for linear than branched aldehydes. As a result, the acetalization of linear aldehydes with EG was faster than that of branched aldehydes, resulting in the high selectivity of linear acetals [14]. The tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction is influenced by the reaction temperature and pressure ( CO: H2) in various modes (Fig. 4C, 4D). The reaction temperature influences the hydroformylation and acetalization activities in different manners (Fig. 4C). For a detailed study of the effects of reaction temperature, the HFA was carried out at different temperatures (60–100 °C). As shown in Fig. 4C, the selectivity of cyclic acetals gradually increased from 35 to 100% with 65% linear acetals when the temperature increased from 60 to 80 °C. Selectivity towards cyclic acetals decreased to 67% when the reaction was conducted at 100 °C due to the formation of hydrogenated product (ethylbenzene). We can conclude from the temperature variation studies that the highest selectivity of cyclic acetals (99%) was obtained at 80 °C. These results demonstrated that a suitable reaction temperature was critical in confirming the high acetal selectivity. For further optimization study, we performed this reaction at 20–40 bar (CO: H2 1:1) pressure Fig. 4D. From this study, we observed that the conversion of styrene gradually increased with increasing pressure from 20 to 30 bar after that, conversion is stable (100%) and the formation of cyclic acetals is nearly stable. Nevertheless, it gradually decreases with increasing pressure from 30 to 40 bar to 73% cyclic acetals selectivity. Again, decreasing acetals selectivity may be due to styrene hydrogenation to ethylbenzene in high concentrate H2. To the best of our knowledge and reported literature, our catalyst gives the best result in mild reaction conditions (See SI Table S2). In addition, we investigated the catalytic activity of 2%Rh@ZrP material with reaction time shown in Fig. 5 A. The acetals' selectivity increased unexpectedly in the first hours and there was no increase in the selectivity of linear acetals after prolonged reaction time. For the leaching study, we performed a hot filtration test in the previous reports (Fig. 5B [14]). The experiment was carried out similarly to the standard catalytic test, with a shorter reaction time (1 h). After the reactor was cooled to room temperature, the remaining CO+H2 was released under a fume hood. The catalyst was then separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The reaction mixture was stirred under the same conditions for further catalytic evaluation. There was no discernible change in the conversion of styrene. But there is some change in acetals formation, it may be due to minor leaching of the catalyst. Following the successful tandem hydroformylation-acetalization of styrene and ethylene glycol, the reaction protocol was extended to various olefins and ethylene glycol to yield an acetal, the results of which are summarized in Table 2 , and the product was confirmed by GCMS (See SI fig. S3–15). Ethylene glycol is widely used in the production of fructone via the protection of the carbonyl group, which is widely used in the pharmaceutical, cosmetic and fragrance industries [12,58]. The scope of the established decorum was extended for the hydroformylation-acetalization of a variety of other olefins, and the results found are summarised in Table 2. The model substrate styrene and EG gave complete conversion with 99% selectivity towards cyclic acetals with 65% selectivity towards linear cyclic acetals (Table 2A). Compared with the reported literature, high selectivity towards linear acetals was obtained over 2% for Rh@ZrP catalysts in the tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction of styrene (See SI Table S2). Furthermore, the electronic effect of a variety of electron-withdrawing groups (EWG) like Cl or Br and electron-donating groups (EDG) like CH3, t-Bu, or OCH3 on substituted styrene was investigated (Table 2, Entry B-F). Linear cyclic acetals were the desired products when substituted styrenes were used for this reaction (61–67%). When EWG was used, it had lower selectivity for linear aldehyde (61–62%) than EDG (65–67%) Table 2. Later we used methanol as an alcohol source and to our surprise, we got 100% conversion with 99% selectivity of acetals and 65% selectivity of linear acetals. Additionally, we tested the activity of catalysts with other diols and found that the catalysts had a similar activity (Table 2. Entry H and I). As a result, we have focused our efforts on aliphatic shorter to long-chain olefins. Fortunately, the selectivity of acetal ranged from moderate to high selectivity (60–99%). This reaction was attractive due to the synthesis of acetals like 1,3 dioxolane derivatives and 2-alkyl dioxolane in the same pot, which are commonly used as additives in gasoline and diesel, which are promising substitutes for ethanol and methyl tertbutyl ether (MTBE) [59,60]. Importantly, ethylene gives only one acetal, i.e. 2 ethyl 1,3 dioxolane (83%), which is an important fuel additive. Further chain length was increased from C3 C12 and surprisingly, we got a high yield of cyclic acetals (60–99%). When the chain length of terminal olefins increased from C3 C12 it gave branched selective cyclic acetals (Table 2. Entry J-P). Investigation of active sites and possible reaction mechanisms Rhodium oxide nanoparticles on zirconium phosphate support proved to be effective in tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction. Based on the observation, 2%Rh@ZrP has strongly influenced the synthesis of cyclic acetals directly from olefins. This heterogeneous bifunctional catalyst was prepared by a simple refluxing method and gave up to 99% selectivity of cyclic acetals with complete conversion of olefins under mild conditions. In this study, rhodium was preferred owing to its high catalytic activity in hydroformylation reaction and zirconium phosphate plays a Brønsted acidic role, which is beneficial in the acetalization reaction. However, the synergy between rhodium oxide nanoparticles and acidic sites of zirconium phosphates in this bifunctional catalyst results in excellent catalytic activity and selectivity of cyclic acetals. According to an earlier literature report, strong mineral acids (HCl, H2SO4), organic acids, Lewis acids, and solid acids were used in the acetalization reaction. [6,7,9] The plausible mechanism for the tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction of olefins is illustrated in Scheme 3 based on the existing proofs and the experimentally obtained results. The first catalytic cycle is similar to the previously described hydroformylation reaction. The presence of oxygen and phosphorus atoms in the material increases the electron density towards the rhodium surface, resulting in the adsorption of alkene and carbon monoxide. The probable mechanism of hydroformylation-acetalization begins with the coordination of an olefin to the surface of rhodium oxide (A) followed by the migratory insertion of hydrogen to make alkyl (B) and finally, carbon monoxide inserted into rhodium and alkyl bond to make acyl (C). Finally, H2 coordinates, hydrogenolysis occurs, and an aldehyde product is formed after reductive elimination. Furthermore, acetalization of aldehyde occurs in ethylene glycol in the following cycle. The eliminated aldehyde from the first cycle reacts with the acidic proton of zirconium phosphate to form the oxonium ion (E) intermediate in this cycle. The resulting intermediate is unstable, and it further reacts with the nucleophilic ethylene glycol to form the stable five numbered cyclic acetals. From an industrial and economical point of view, separation and recyclability are the critical parameters for heterogeneous catalysts. As a result, the reusability of the most active catalyst (2% Rh@ZrP) was investigated. Following the completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation and washed with methanol to remove any unreacted or reacted substances on the catalyst surface. The washed catalyst was then dried in a hot air oven at 80°C for 12 h before reuse. For the fresh catalyst, under the optimized conditions, the conversion of styrene to cyclic acetals was 100% in just 6 h at 80°C. After the first cycle in the HFA reaction, 98% conversion and 97% selectivity towards cyclic acetals were observed (Table 3 . Entry 1). When the catalyst was used for the 3rd cycle, 98% conversions (See SI Fig. S19) with 0.03 mmol of Rh, leaching was observed by ICP analysis (Table 3. Entry 2). For the leaching study, the reaction mixture was collected to find any rhodium content for the first cycle and we observed that 0.003 mmol of Rh was leached from ICP. To evaluate the possibility of a reaction occurring in supernatant liquid, we performed the reaction with the same amount of styrene at the identical reaction condition, and we did not observe any conversion of styrene (Table 3. Entry 3). The structural configuration of the catalyst remained unchanged until the third recycle, which confirms the constancy of rhodium in support. The SEM-EDAX, TEM, and XPS spectra of the recycled catalyst shown in SI, Fig. S20–22, and Table S2 show the catalyst's stability. Conclusion In conclusion, we developed a novel effective, and green route for the synthesis of 2 ethyl-1,3 dioxolane and other cyclic acetals from aliphatic and aromatic terminal olefins by tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction over Rh-based heterogeneous catalyst under mild reaction conditions. Compared to traditional ways, this procedure is simple, with easy separation of catalyst and recycling up to three without significant loss of activity. Based on the obtained results, it can be concluded that 2wt% of Rh loading on ZrP is ample to complete the conversion of olefins with the selectivity of cyclic acetals (up to 99%) under suitable reaction conditions (80°C, 30 bar, 6 h). Furthermore, the selectivity for desired linear cyclic acetals in the case of styrene and branched selective for aliphatic C3 C12 olefins enhanced this cascade reaction as compared to a simple hydroformylation reaction. Based on the experimental results, we conclude that Rh oxide nanoparticles and surface acidic sites on zirconium support are responsible for the tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction. Additionally, a wide range of acetals can be synthesized using various olefins and diols with excellent yield. CRediT authorship contribution statement Amravati S. coredata.dc:description: A novel sustainable approach for the synthesis of 2-ethyl 1,3 dioxolane and various short to long-chain or aromatic cyclic acetals through a tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction using Rh oxide nanoparticle supported on zirconium phosphate has been established. The Rh oxide nanoparticle supported on zirconium phosphate was synthesized and characterized by various physicochemical methods. The SEM and TEM analysis revealed the average particle size of rhodium oxide was found to be ∼7.56 nm in 2%Rh@ZrP catalyst. Furthermore, the synthesized catalyst was employed to carry out a tandem hydroformylation reaction in a green solvent (ethylene glycol). Experimental results demonstrated that 2 wt.% of Rhodium on zirconium phosphate efficiently activated olefins, leading to the selective formation of cyclic acetals (60–99%) at 80°C for 6 h. In this cascade reaction, significant selectivity towards the desired product, linear cyclic acetals was observed for styrenes. This can be attributed to highly dispersed Rh oxide nanoparticles and plentiful acidic sites on the zirconium phosphate supports, which played a crucial role in tandem hydroformylation and acetalization reactions. The catalyst exhibited the ability to be reused three times without losing significant catalytic activity or selectivity. This is the first report on the synthesis of a fuel additive and other cyclic acetals via a tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction using heterogeneous catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst: A sustainable route for cyclic acetals synthesis through tandem hydroformylation-acetalization reaction
